subject: Home & DIY
title: Why Overloaded Outlets Start Fires
description: One-minute skill: Why Overloaded Outlets Start Fires.

hook.text: A single outlet is rated for 15 amps. Plug in a space heater, hair dryer, and toaster, and you've tripled the safe load.

buildup.text: Every wire has resistance. When current exceeds the rating, resistance generates heatâ€”wires inside your walls get hot.

discovery.text: Breakers should trip before wires overheat. But loose connections and corrosion can delay the trip just long enough.

twist.text: Extension cords don't add circuit capacityâ€”they just let you plug in more devices than the wiring can handle.

climax.text: Electrical fires kill 300+ Americans yearly. Most start inside walls where hot wires touch insulation or wood.

punchline.text: More plugs don't mean more power.

quiz.question: What happens when you exceed an outlet's rated amperage?
options: Wire resistance generates heat that can ignite wall materials
The outlet immediately shuts off to protect the circuit
The connected devices simply run at reduced power
